Ghising has no party machine, parliamentary bloc, or precedent of such a leap; caretaker ministers almost never become full PMs immediately. Even with the Gen-Z movement’s outsized role in precipitating the caretaker government, the process for selecting a permanent PM is controlled by parliamentary arithmetic and party agreement. Ghising’s popularity provides a very slim, outside path—should the election lead to continued deadlock, and the new mass movement insists. But this is highly improbable: the most compelling scenario is a reassertion of party politics after the acute caretaker period. I incorporate 3-5% for high-impact tail events (new violence, protest paralyzing parliament, party system collapse), but overall assign very low odds on Ghising becoming the next non-caretaker PM.

South Asian Studies (Nepalese Political.perspective_relevance: My expertise in South Asian Studies with a focus on Nepalese political history equips me to contextualize current events within Nepal's unique patterns of elite contestation, youth protest, constitutional norms, and post-conflict institutional fragility. Recent history (since 2006) includes abrupt government collapses, intense street politics, and the periodic rise of technocrats or reformist outsiders under public pressure, but persistent institutional norms often favor established party figures or those who can broker cross-party/army deals.
South Asian Studies (Nepalese Political.status_quo: Nepal is under a caretaker government led by Sushila Karki, with Kulman Ghising serving as energy minister. The system is in a holding pattern until fresh elections scheduled for March 2026; Ghising is not currently PM.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability moderately—Ghising has a strong reputation as a corruption fighter and practical technocrat, admired by the Gen-Z movement and a hero to many for ending Nepal's energy crisis. The Gen-Z protests have propelled unlikely candidates to prominence.

Decreases probability—Nepal’s constitutional arrangements and the historical behavior of the president, military, and major parties tend to favor either experienced politicians or well-respected institutional figures (e.g., former Chief Justice Karki) in transitions. Nepal has rarely (perhaps never) elevated a technocratic figure directly from minister/agency chief to PM except under coalition party support.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Gen-Z Movement and Youth Street Power
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Moderately increases probability—The extraordinary influence of protest movements this cycle means outsiders like Ghising may have unusually high leverage, and the chaos may permit a break with precedent.

South Asian Studies (Nepalese Political.no_scenario: Nepal proceeds under the interim Karki government, holds elections in March 2026, and the major parties nominate one of their own as the next PM. South Asian Studies (Nepalese Political.yes_scenario: Extreme instability or a new crisis (e.g., the interim government collapses) results in public and elite consensus for a non-partisan, technocratic PM. Ghising's strong anti-corruption credentials, popularity with Gen-Z, and prior recognition as a trustworthy crisis manager lead the president, army, and key factions to appoint him as PM, and he wins the parliamentary confidence vote between Sep 11, 2025 and Jan 1, 2026. This would require the interim government to fall and elite/Gen-Z compromise to coalesce around Ghising—an unlikely but not impossible 'break-glass' scenario.
South Asian Studies (Nepalese Political.final_reasoning: While Kulman Ghising enjoys rare cross-generational popularity—especially among the Gen-Z movement—and was part of the inner circle of cabinet formation, all public, legal, and practical signals point to his current ceiling as a (powerful) interim minister. His path to the prime ministership in the relevant timeframe would require either: (A) the interim Karki government collapsing and political actors agreeing (against precedent and large-party interests) to make him PM in a non-caretaker capacity, OR (B) the implementation of a novel solution outside established party/army channels. The base rate of technocrats becoming PM outside party sponsorship is near-zero in Nepal's post-2006 history. Furthermore, all public statements and media coverage since the protests identify Sushila Karki as interim PM until the election, with Ghising as her energy minister—nothing supports an imminent switch. The military, president, and parties have little incentive to endorse Ghising unless a wholly new breakdown/consensus emerges. Therefore, weighted most heavily toward the status quo (Karki until elections, then a party leader), but allowing a sliver of probability on revolutionary exceptionalism given the unusual political environment.

South Asian Studies (Regional Power Dyna.perspective_relevance: As a South Asian regional power dynamics expert, I bring deep insight into Nepal’s civil-military relations, elite politics, social movements, and historical succession processes. Understanding the interplay among mass protests, caretaker arrangements, and the evolving power of youth-led (Gen Z) movements, as well as how extra-parliamentary pressures and institutional constraints shape the emergence of new political leaders, places me in a strong position to analyze the plausibility of a technocratic figure like Kulman Ghising becoming the next permanent/non-caretaker prime minister.

question_details.title: Who will be the next non-caretaker prime minister of Nepal? (Kulman Ghising)
question_details.description:
The Federal: [Who could be Nepal's next prime minister? Here are 5 top contenders](https://thefederal.com/category/international/nepals-next-prime-minister-after-olis-controversial-exit-206263)

> Scuffles were reported among Gen-Z factions backing different contenders outside the Nepal Army headquarters in Kathmandu on Wednesday evening, as talks to pick an interim leader after the violent overthrow of the government extended into the third day.

> KP Sharma Oli resigned as prime minister on Tuesday, leaving the post vacant while the anti-corruption revolt continues without a clear leader.

question_details.resolution_criteria:
This question is a subquestion of a group question. This subquestion specifically targets the option 'Kulman Ghising'. The resolution criteria for the parent question is below. 

This question resolves as **Yes** for the individual who, after September 11, 2025 and before January 1, 2026 takes the [oath](https://www.constituteproject.org/constitution/Nepal_2016#s852) of office and secrecy as the new [Prime Minister of Nepal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Nepal) and wins a vote of confidence in the House of Representatives as required by [section 76](https://www.constituteproject.org/constitution/Nepal_2016#s795) of the Constitution of Nepal. The question resolves as **No** for everyone else. If none of the listed candidates fulfills the criteria during that time period, then the question resolves as **No** for every option.
question_details.fine_print: This is a Group question, so you do not have to assess probabilities for every option. More options may be added after the question opens, if there is [credible](https://www.metaculus.com/faq/#definitions) reporting that a particular individual has a material probability of coming the next PM of Nepal.

Here are the relevant news articles:

**Nepal's interim PM appoints cabinet amid post-protest recovery**
In an effort to stabilize Nepal after deadly anti‑government protests, Prime Minister Sushila Karki, the country’s first female prime minister, appointed an interim cabinet on Monday.  The new ministers—Kalman Gurung as energy minister, Rameshore Khanal as finance minister, and Om Prakash Aryal as home minister—were sworn in outside a government building that had been attacked and set ablaze by protesters the week before.  The appointments come after violent demonstrations sparked by a brief social media ban and widespread anger over corruption that resulted in at least 72 deaths and hundreds of injuries, leading to the collapse of the previous administration.  Karki, 73, who was appointed on September 12, took office following an agreement with leaders of the largely youth‑led ‘Gen Z’ protest movement.  The military, which enforced a curfew during the unrest, ultimately consented to her leadership of a caretaker government charged with overseeing elections within six months.  At a conference on Sunday, Karki stated, 'What we need now is to work to end corruption, bring about good governance, and achieve economic equality. This is what the people truly desire at this moment.'  Businessman Shrawan Dahl expressed confidence in her ability to lead, saying, 'Her objective is to conduct the election, and we hope she will accomplish this task successfully.'
Original language: en
Publish date: September 15, 2025 03:28 PM
Source:[Africanews](https://www.africanews.com/2025/09/15/nepals-interim-pm-appoints-cabinet-amid-post-protest-recovery/)

**Nepal's PM Karki appoints ministers after deadly Gen Z protests**
Neal's Prime Minister Sushila Karki, the country’s first female leader, appointed Om Prakash Aryal as home minister, Rameshwar Prasad Khanal as finance minister, and Kulman Ghising as energy minister on Monday, following the dissolution of parliament after deadly protests that killed at least 72 people. Aryal is a human‑rights lawyer, Khanal a former finance secretary who recommended major economic reforms, and Ghising a former state power utility chief credited with eliminating load‑shedding. President Ramchandra Paudel swore them in during a televised ceremony outside the fire‑damaged presidential office. The interim government, which will last six months until early‑March elections, is pledged to tackle corruption. The appointments came less than a week after former PM KP Sharma Oli resigned amid unrest that escalated when demonstrators were shot dead by police on Monday. The protests, led by Gen Z, began on 8 September over a brief social‑media ban and grew into widespread anger over corruption and poverty. In her first public remarks, Karki said the country should rebuild together and would work 'according to the thinking of the Gen Z generation'. Subash Dhakal, a 19‑year‑old protester shot in the knees, told AFP he had no regrets and that the pain was temporary but would bring change.
Original language: en
Publish date: September 15, 2025 12:46 PM
Source:[Al Jazeera Online](https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2025/9/15/nepals-pm-karki-appoints-ministers-after-deadly-gen-z-protests)

**Nepal PM Sushila Karki appoints three new ministers for interim cabinet**
On September 15 2025, the Hindustan Times reported that Nepal President Ramchandra Paudel swore in three ministers—Kulman Ghising, Rameshwor Khanal and Om Prakash Aryal—appointed by caretaker Prime Minister Sushila Karki for her newly formed cabinet. The oath ceremony took place at the President's Office, Sheetal Niwas, Maharajgunj, after which all three ministers immediately assumed their posts. Khanal, the former finance secretary, was sworn in as finance minister. Ghising, the former managing director of the Nepal Electricity Authority, was given charge of energy, water resources and irrigation; physical infrastructure and transport; and urban development. Aryal, an advocate, was appointed minister for home affairs and for law, justice and parliamentary affairs. The article notes that Karki, 73, became Nepal's first female prime minister on September 12, at the recommendation of the agitating 'Gen Z' group, to lead a caretaker government tasked with conducting fresh elections on March 5 2026. It also recounts that former Prime Minister KP Sharma Oli resigned after widespread anti‑government protests led by the 'Gen Z' group against a social media ban and corruption allegations; the protests turned violent, with at least 72 people losing their lives in the nationwide unrest.

**Army out, curfew clamped as Nepal hunts for a new leader**
On September 10, 2025, soldiers guarded Nepal’s parliament and patrolled deserted streets under a curfew after Prime Minister KP Sharma Oli resigned amid deadly anti‑corruption protests. The death toll had risen to 25 and 633 were injured, according to the health ministry. In addition, five juvenile inmates died during a clash with security at a western Nepal jail, and more than 7,000 prisoners escaped from prisons nationwide. Negotiations between representatives and protesters began at the army headquarters, but no succession plan was agreed upon. Tribhuvan International Airport resumed services the same evening, 24 hours after closing. The army deployed armoured personnel carriers and used loudspeakers to call for calm. Former PM Jhala Nath Khanal’s wife, Ravi Laxmi Chitrakar, who sustained serious burn injuries, is critical but stable, as reported by Dr Kiran Nakarmi of Kirtipur Hospital. **After Oli's exit, who will lead Nepal? Inside details of GenZ meeting on Interim Government - The Statesman**
Violent Gen Z protests over alleged corruption and nepotism have erupted across Nepal, with demonstrators setting fire to the Parliament building and the residences of the President, Prime Minister and several ministers. Prime Minister KP Sharma Oli resigned amid the unrest, and a meeting of Gen Z protesters and allies was held on 18 September 2025 at Jangi Adda, Army Headquarters in Bhadrakali, Kathmandu, to discuss who should lead the interim government. The meeting considered several potential leaders: Kathmandu Mayor Balenndra Shah, former Chief Justice Shushila Karki (who said 'I am ready to lead the interim government if I have unanimous support'), Sumana Shrestha (who declined due to her affiliation with the Rastriya Swatantra Party), Harka Samparg (Mayor of Dharan), Sagar Dhakal (federal election candidate), Kulman Ghising (former Managing Director of Nepal Electricity Authority), and Rastra Bimochan Timalsena (YouTuber and lawyer who goes by 'Random Nepali').

summary: Across a diverse panel of experts—including comparative politics analysts, Nepal political journalists, political scientists, and South Asian regional specialists—consensus is strongly against the likelihood of Kulman Ghising becoming the next non-caretaker prime minister of Nepal before January 1, 2026. All experts note the current status quo: Sushila Karki is serving as interim/caretaker PM after Gen-Z-led protests, and elections are scheduled for March 2026. Ghising, a popular technocrat and energy minister, enjoys public support and some backing among Gen-Z activists, but lacks deep party infrastructure, a legislative base, or a history of coalition brokering—key prerequisites for the premiership in Nepal’s parliamentary system. The base rates from Nepali political history heavily favor senior party leaders as PMs, especially after crisis caretaker periods. While several experts allow for a minor increase in Ghising's odds due to the unusual context of Gen-Z protest influence and current political volatility, all stress that the constitutional caretaker mandate and entrenched party dominance render a leap from technocratic minister to permanent PM extremely improbable. Only unprecedented crisis, total party collapse, or extraordinary consensus among elite actors and protest movements could create an opening for Ghising, and current signals and institutional incentives do not support this. Expert probability estimates cluster tightly between 2% and 10%, with most (and the modal value) between 2–4%. The group chat and independent analyses reinforce that, barring a major rupture or shock, the post-caretaker PM will likely be a party-backed figure, not Ghising.
